title: Jameis Winston
text:
Jameis Lanaed Winston ( ; born January 6, 1994) is an <a href="American%20football">American football</a> <a href="quarterback">quarterback</a> for the <a href="New%20Orleans%20Saints">New Orleans Saints</a> of the <a href="National%20Football%20League">National Football League</a> (NFL). He played <a href="college%20football">college football</a> at <a href="Florida%20State%20University">Florida State</a>, where he became the youngest player to win the <a href="Heisman%20Trophy">Heisman Trophy</a> and led his team to victory in the <a href="2014%20BCS%20National%20Championship%20Game">2014 BCS National Championship Game</a> during his freshman year. Declaring for the NFL after his sophomore season, Winston was selected <a href="List%20of%20first%20overall%20National%20Football%20League%20draft%20picks">first overall</a> by the <a href="Tampa%20Bay%20Buccaneers">Tampa Bay Buccaneers</a> in the <a href="2015%20NFL%20Draft">2015 NFL Draft</a>.
Winston set several franchise rookie records for the Buccaneers, earning him <a href="Pro%20Bowl">Pro Bowl</a> honors, and led the league in passing yards during the 2019 season. However, he was unable to reach the playoffs with the Buccaneers and his 2019 campaign was also marked by him leading the league in interceptions, including setting the NFL season record for interceptions returned for touchdowns. Not re-signed to Tampa Bay after his rookie contract expired, Winston joined the Saints as a backup to <a href="Drew%20Brees">Drew Brees</a>. He became the team's primary starter in 2021 following Brees' retirement.
Early life.
Winston was born in <a href="Bessemer%2C%20Alabama">Bessemer, Alabama</a> on January 6, 1994. He attended <a href="Hueytown%20High%20School">Hueytown High School</a>, where he played both <a href="American%20football">football</a> and <a href="baseball">baseball</a>. Winston was considered the best <a href="Quarterback%23Dual-threat%20quarterbacks">dual-threat quarterback</a> recruit in the nation by <a href="Rivals.com">Rivals.com</a>, and the best overall quarterback recruit by <a href="ESPN">ESPN</a>. Winston was also named the MVP of the <a href="ESPN%20RISE%20Elite%2011">ESPN RISE Elite 11</a> quarterback camp. Additionally, Winston earned the Gatorade Player of the Year recognition for the state of Alabama.
Winston committed to attend <a href="Florida%20State%20University">Florida State University</a> on February 3, 2012. The <a href="Texas%20Rangers%20%28baseball%29">Texas Rangers</a> selected Winston in the 15th round of the <a href="2012%20Major%20League%20Baseball%20Draft">2012 Major League Baseball Draft</a> out of high school. Though the Rangers proposed allowing him to play for the <a href="Florida%20State%20Seminoles%20football">Florida State Seminoles football</a> team while working out with their baseball organization, Winston decided not to sign.
College career.
Football.
2012 season.
Winston <a href="redshirted">redshirted</a> during the 2012 college football season behind senior quarterback <a href="EJ%20Manuel">EJ Manuel</a>.
2013 season.
Prior to the 2013 season, Winston was named Florida State's starting quarterback. In his college debut, he completed 25 of 27 passes with four passing touchdowns along with a rushing touchdown in a 41–17 victory over the <a href="2013%20Pittsburgh%20Panthers%20football">University of Pittsburgh</a>.
Winston helped lead the team to an undefeated 13–0 regular season record, including a 45–7 victory in the <a href="2013%20ACC%20Championship%20Game">ACC Championship</a> against <a href="2013%20Duke%20Blue%20Devils%20football%20team">Duke</a>.
For his successes in 2013, Winston earned numerous accolades. He was named the 2013 ACC Offensive Player of the Year and ACC Player of the Year to go along with winning the AP Player of the Year Award, Davey O'Brien Award, Manning Award, and Walter Camp Player of the Year Award. In addition, he was named as a Consensus All-American. Most notably, he won the <a href="Heisman%20Trophy">Heisman Trophy</a> on December 14, 2013, beating out quarterbacks <a href="A.%20J.%20McCarron">A. J. McCarron</a>, <a href="Jordan%20Lynch">Jordan Lynch</a>, and <a href="Johnny%20Manziel">Johnny Manziel</a>, the previous winner, as well as running backs <a href="Tre%20Mason">Tre Mason</a> and <a href="Andre%20Williams%20%28American%20football%29">Andre Williams</a>. He became the second freshman to win the award, after Manziel won the previous year. He also became the youngest to win the award, at 19 years and 342 days.
On January 6, 2014, Winston's 20th birthday, Florida State defeated <a href="2013%20Auburn%20Tigers%20football%20team">Auburn</a> 34–31 in the <a href="2014%20BCS%20National%20Championship%20Game">2014 BCS National Championship Game</a>. Winston was named the Offensive MVP of the game after passing for 235 yards with two touchdowns, including the game-winning touchdown pass to <a href="Kelvin%20Benjamin">Kelvin Benjamin</a> with 13 seconds left. Winston finished his freshman season with a conference-leading 4,057 passing yards and 40 passing touchdowns, which set an <a href="Atlantic%20Coast%20Conference">ACC</a> record and a <a href="NCAA%20Division%20I%20Football%20Bowl%20Subdivision">Division I Football Bowl Subdivision</a> freshman record.
2014 season.
Winston started 13 games his redshirt sophomore season. He did not play in one game due to suspension. After a 13–0 regular season, the Seminoles were selected to play in the <a href="2015%20Rose%20Bowl">2015 Rose Bowl</a>, a semifinal game in the <a href="College%20Football%20Playoff">College Football Playoff</a>, against <a href="2014%20Oregon%20Ducks%20football%20team">Oregon</a>. Oregon would win the game by a score of 59–20, giving Winston his only loss as a starter during his college career. Winston finished the season with a conference-leading 3,907 passing yards and 25 touchdowns. He finished in sixth place in the Heisman Trophy voting in 2014.
After the season, Winston decided to forgo the remaining two years of eligibility and enter the <a href="2015%20NFL%20Draft">2015 NFL Draft</a>. He finished his career 26–1 as a starter and completed 562 of 851 passes for 7,964 yards, 65 touchdowns, and 28 interceptions.
Baseball.
Winston chose Florida State in part because he was allowed to play for the <a href="Florida%20State%20Seminoles%20baseball">Florida State Seminoles baseball</a> team in addition to football. A <a href="Switch%20hitter">switch-hitting</a> batter and a right-handed thrower, he played as an <a href="outfielder">outfielder</a> and a <a href="pitcher">pitcher</a> as a freshman in 2013. He <a href="batting%20average%20%28baseball%29">batted</a> .235 with a .723 <a href="on-base%20plus%20slugging">on-base plus slugging</a> in 119 <a href="at-bat">at-bat</a>s and had a 3.00 <a href="earned%20run%20average">earned run average</a> in 27 <a href="innings%20pitched">innings pitched</a>. Prior to the 2014 season, Winston was named a preseason All-American by "<a href="Baseball%20America">Baseball America</a>" as a 3rd-team utility player.
Professional career.
Tampa Bay Buccaneers.
2015 season.
The <a href="Tampa%20Bay%20Buccaneers">Tampa Bay Buccaneers</a> took Winston first overall in the <a href="2015%20NFL%20Draft">2015 NFL Draft</a>. On May 1, 2015, Winston signed a four-year, $23.35 million contract with the Buccaneers, with a $16.7 million signing bonus. The contract prevents him from playing any other sport than football.
Winston played his first regular season game against the <a href="2015%20Tennessee%20Titans%20season">Tennessee Titans</a> that featured fellow first rounder, <a href="Marcus%20Mariota">Marcus Mariota</a>. In the 42–14 loss, his first pass was intercepted and returned for a touchdown by <a href="Coty%20Sensabaugh">Coty Sensabaugh</a>. Winston's interception returned for a touchdown was the first time a rookie's first pass since <a href="Brett%20Favre">Brett Favre</a> in 1991.
On November 22, 2015, against the <a href="2015%20Philadelphia%20Eagles%20season">Philadelphia Eagles</a>, Winston tied an NFL rookie, and Buccaneers franchise, record with five touchdown passes.
Winston set franchise rookie records in pass attempts, pass completions, passing yards, and passing touchdowns. Winston finished his rookie season with 4,042 passing yards, finishing 23 yards short of the franchise record set by <a href="Josh%20Freeman">Josh Freeman</a> in 2012. Winston also became the third rookie quarterback to pass over 4,000 yards in a season. He was named to the NFL All-Rookie Team for his 2015 season, becoming the fourth Buccaneers quarterback to receive this award, joining <a href="Tom%20Owen%20%28American%20football%29">Tom Owen</a> (1974), <a href="Doug%20Williams%20%28quarterback%29">Doug Williams</a> (1978), and <a href="Mike%20Glennon">Mike Glennon</a> (2013).
Following his team's loss in the AFC Championship game, <a href="New%20England%20Patriots">New England Patriots</a> quarterback <a href="Tom%20Brady">Tom Brady</a> elected not to participate in the <a href="2016%20Pro%20Bowl">2016 Pro Bowl</a>; as a result, Winston was selected to his first Pro Bowl game making him the first rookie quarterback in Buccaneers' history to be selected.
2016 season.
Winston's second season in the NFL began with an impressive performance against the <a href="2016%20Atlanta%20Falcons%20season">Atlanta Falcons</a> at the <a href="Georgia%20Dome">Georgia Dome</a>, in which he completed over 70% of his throws for 281 yards and four touchdown passes in a 31–24 victory. He earned NFC Offensive Player of the Week for his performance against the Falcons. Following Week 1, the Buccaneers began to struggle through injuries, inconsistent play, and offensive turnovers till mid-season, at which point the team was 3–5 and had experienced blowout losses to the <a href="2016%20Arizona%20Cardinals%20season">Arizona Cardinals</a>, <a href="2016%20Denver%20Broncos%20season">Denver Broncos</a>, and Atlanta Falcons - a three-game losing streak. Following the loss to the Falcons, the Winston-led Buccaneers began playing efficient offense as well as exceptional defense and special teams play, resulting in the Buccaneers' first five-game winning streak since their Super Bowl-winning <a href="2002%20Tampa%20Bay%20Buccaneers%20season">season</a>. The win streak gave the Buccaneers possession of the 6th seed in the NFC playoff race, which they quickly lost after back-to-back losses to the <a href="2016%20Dallas%20Cowboys%20season">Dallas Cowboys</a> and <a href="2016%20New%20Orleans%20Saints%20season">New Orleans Saints</a>. Winston led the Buccaneers to their first winning season in six years after defeating the <a href="2016%20Carolina%20Panthers%20season">Carolina Panthers</a> in the regular-season finale, during which he broke the franchise records for passing yards and passing touchdowns in a season and became the first quarterback in NFL history to start his career with consecutive seasons of 4,000 yards passing. However, the Buccaneers were eliminated from playoff contention via a tiebreaker with the <a href="2016%20Detroit%20Lions%20season">Detroit Lions</a>. He was ranked 57th by his peers on the <a href="NFL%20Top%20100%20Players%20of%202017">NFL Top 100 Players of 2017</a>.
2017 season.
During Week 6 against the <a href="2017%20Arizona%20Cardinals%20season">Arizona Cardinals</a>, Winston left the game with an apparent right shoulder injury. The next day, October 16, Winston suffered a sprained AC joint in his right shoulder, but he stated that he could play through it. During Week 9's loss to the <a href="2017%20New%20Orleans%20Saints%20season">New Orleans Saints</a>, Winston was taken out of the game with the same shoulder injury. Head coach <a href="Dirk%20Koetter">Dirk Koetter</a> announced the next day that he would miss at least two weeks to rest his shoulder. While on the sideline, Winston initiated an altercation with Saints rookie <a href="Marshon%20Lattimore">Marshon Lattimore</a>, while being assisted by teammate Mike Evans, for which Winston was fined $12,154. In the game, Winston became the second-youngest player in NFL history to reach 10,000 career passing yards, four days older than record holder <a href="Drew%20Bledsoe">Drew Bledsoe</a>. He missed the next three games due to injury and returned in Week 13. Overall, Winston and Buccaneers struggled to a 5–11 record. Winston finished the 2017 season with 3,504 passing yards, 19 touchdowns, and 11 interceptions.
2018 season.
On April 17, 2018, the Buccaneers picked up the fifth-year option on Winston's contract. On June 21, the NFL announced that he would be suspended for violating the league's personal conduct policy, regarding his latest incident where he allegedly groped a female <a href="Uber">Uber</a> driver. On June 28, the announcement was made official, giving Winston a three-game suspension to begin the 2018 season.
After missing the first three games due to the suspension, Winston returned in Week 4 against the <a href="2018%20Chicago%20Bears%20season">Chicago Bears</a>, but did not start. He replaced <a href="Ryan%20Fitzpatrick">Ryan Fitzpatrick</a> in the third quarter, finishing with 145 passing yards, a touchdown, and two interceptions as the Buccaneers lost 10–48. In Week 6, against the <a href="2018%20Atlanta%20Falcons%20season">Atlanta Falcons</a>, he had 395 passing yards, four touchdowns, and two interceptions in the 34–29 loss. In Week 8 against the <a href="2018%20Cincinnati%20Bengals%20season">Cincinnati Bengals</a>, Winston threw for 276 yards, one touchdown, and four interceptions and he was benched in the third quarter for Fitzpatrick. During Week 11 against the <a href="2018%20New%20York%20Giants%20season">New York Giants</a>, Fitzpatrick threw three interceptions and was benched for Winston in the second half. Winston threw for 199 yards, two touchdowns, and an interception as the Buccaneers lost 38–35. Two weeks later, in a 24–17 win over the <a href="2018%20Carolina%20Panthers%20season">Carolina Panthers</a>, Winston completed 20 of 30 passing attempts for 249 yards and two touchdowns, breaking the franchise record for passing touchdowns in a career with 81. Three weeks later, in a 27–20 loss to the <a href="2018%20Dallas%20Cowboys%20season">Dallas Cowboys</a>, Winston completed 34 of 48 passing attempts for 336 yards and one touchdown, breaking the franchise record for completions in a career previously held by <a href="Josh%20Freeman">Josh Freeman</a>. Overall, he finished the 2018 season with 2,992 passing yards, 19 touchdowns, and 14 interceptions.
2019 season.
Prior to the start of the season, head coach <a href="Dirk%20Koetter">Dirk Koetter</a> was fired and replaced by former <a href="Arizona%20Cardinals">Arizona Cardinals</a> head coach <a href="Bruce%20Arians">Bruce Arians</a>. In Week 1, during a 31–17 loss to the <a href="2019%20San%20Francisco%2049ers">San Francisco 49ers</a>, Winston broke the Buccaneers franchise record for passing yards in a career previously held by <a href="Vinny%20Testaverde">Vinny Testaverde</a> but finished with 194 passing yards, one touchdown, and three interceptions, two of which were returned for touchdowns. Following a lackluster first two weeks of the 2019 season, during a 32–31 loss to the <a href="2019%20New%20York%20Giants%20season">New York Giants</a> in Week 3, Winston passed for 380 yards, three touchdowns, and one interception. The following week, Winston passed for 385 yards, four touchdowns, and an interception in a 55–40 win over the <a href="2019%20Los%20Angeles%20Rams%20season">Los Angeles Rams</a>. As a result of his performance, Winston was named NFC Offensive Player of the Week.
During Week 6 against the <a href="2019%20Carolina%20Panthers%20season">Carolina Panthers</a> at <a href="Tottenham%20Hotspur%20Stadium">Tottenham Hotspur Stadium</a>, Winston became the first quarterback in Buccaneers franchise history to pass for 100 touchdowns in a career, but finished with 400 passing yards, one touchdown, a lost fumble, and a career-high five interceptions as the Buccaneers lost 37–26. Two weeks later, in a 27–23 loss to the <a href="2019%20Tennessee%20Titans%20season">Tennessee Titans</a>, Winston broke another Buccaneers franchise record, previously held by Testaverde, for career passing attempts, but finished with 301 yards, two touchdowns, two interceptions, and two lost fumbles. The following week, in a 40–34 overtime loss to the <a href="2019%20Seattle%20Seahawks%20season">Seattle Seahawks</a>, Winston passed for 335 yards, two touchdowns, and lost a fumble. In Week 10, during a 30–27 victory over the <a href="2019%20Arizona%20Cardinals%20season">Arizona Cardinals</a>, he had 358 passing yards, one touchdown, and two interceptions. In the next against the <a href="2019%20New%20Orleans%20Saints%20season">New Orleans Saints</a>, Winston threw for 313 yards, two touchdowns, and four interceptions, one of which was returned for a touchdown, as the Buccaneers lost 34–17. In Week 12, during a 35–22 win against the <a href="2019%20Atlanta%20Falcons%20season">Atlanta Falcons</a>, Winston passed for 313 yards, three touchdowns, and two interceptions. During Week 14 against the <a href="2019%20Indianapolis%20Colts%20season">Indianapolis Colts</a>, Winston finished with a then career-best 456 passing yards, five rushing yards, five total touchdowns, and three interceptions as the Buccaneers won 38–35. As a result of his performance, Winston broke the Buccaneers' single-season franchise record for passing yards that he set in 2016, becoming the first quarterback in franchise history to pass for over 4,100 yards in a season.
In Week 15, during a 38–17 win over the <a href="2019%20Detroit%20Lions%20season">Detroit Lions</a>, Winston finished with a career-best 458 passing yards, four rushing yards, four touchdowns, and one interception as he both became the first quarterback in NFL history to have consecutive games of 450 passing yards and broke the franchise record for passing touchdowns in a single season that he set in 2016, becoming the first quarterback in franchise history to throw 30 passing touchdowns in a single season. In Week 16, during a 23–20 loss to the <a href="2019%20Houston%20Texans%20season">Houston Texans</a>, Winston threw for 335 yards, one touchdown, and four interceptions with one returned for a touchdown. In Week 17, during a 28–22 overtime loss to the <a href="2019%20Atlanta%20Falcons%20season">Atlanta Falcons</a>, Winston threw for 201 yards, two touchdowns, and two interceptions including a game-ending one that was returned for a touchdown by linebacker <a href="Deion%20Jones">Deion Jones</a>. As a result, Winston became the eighth quarterback in NFL history to throw for 5,000 yards in a single season, the first Buccaneers quarterback to throw for 5,000 yards in a single season, and the first quarterback in NFL history to throw at least 30 touchdowns and 30 interceptions in a single season.
Winston finished his fifth year setting new career highs, leading the league in <a href="List%20of%20National%20Football%20League%20season%20passing%20yardage%20leaders">passing yards</a>, completions, and attempts to go along with new career highs in passing touchdowns but also leading the league in interceptions and total turnovers. He finished with 5,109 passing yards, 33 passing touchdowns, one rushing touchdown, 30 interceptions, and five lost fumbles. Winston's seven interceptions returned for touchdowns set an NFL record, and his 84.3 passer rating ranked 27th among starters.
On February 28, 2020, it was revealed that Winston underwent surgery to repair a torn meniscus. It was also revealed that Winston had <a href="LASIK%20surgery">LASIK surgery</a>. Furthermore, he was dealing with the knee injury and a broken thumb for the entire 2019 season. Winston was not re-signed by the Buccaneers in the offseason, as they opted to replace him with longtime <a href="New%20England%20Patriots">New England Patriots</a> quarterback <a href="Tom%20Brady">Tom Brady</a>.
New Orleans Saints.
2020.
On April 28, 2020, Winston signed a one-year contract with the <a href="New%20Orleans%20Saints">New Orleans Saints</a>. His contract had a value of $1.1 million including his base salary of $952,000 and a signing bonus of $148,000 with a possible $3.4 million in incentives. Winston made his first appearance of the 2020 season in Week 9 against his former team the <a href="Tampa%20Bay%20Buccaneers">Tampa Bay Buccaneers</a> on "<a href="NBC%20Sunday%20Night%20Football">Sunday Night Football</a>" in relief of Brees. Winston passed for 12 yards as the Saints beat the Bucs 38–3. In Week 10 against the <a href="2020%20San%20Francisco%2049ers%20season">San Francisco 49ers</a>, Winston came in the second half after Brees left the game with a rib injury. Winston completed 6 of 10 passes for 63 yards as the Saints won 27–13. He was placed on the reserve/<a href="COVID-19">COVID-19</a> list by the team on December 20, 2020, and activated four days later.
In the Divisional Round of the playoffs against the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, Winston went into the lineup on a trick play and threw a 56-yard touchdown pass to <a href="Tre%27Quan%20Smith">Tre'Quan Smith</a> during the 30–20 loss.
2021.
On March 15, 2021, Winston re-signed with the Saints on a one-year deal worth $12 million. On August 27, 2021, Winston was named the starting quarterback for the Saints over <a href="Taysom%20Hill">Taysom Hill</a>. Making his first start for the Saints against the <a href="2021%20Green%20Bay%20Packers%20season">Green Bay Packers</a>, Winston threw for 147 yards and five touchdowns as the Saints won 38–3. The following week against the <a href="2021%20Carolina%20Panthers%20season">Carolina Panthers</a> with multiple starters injured and seven coaches sidelined due to <a href="COVID-19">COVID-19</a> Winston threw for 111 yards and 2 interceptions with no touchdowns in the 26–7 loss. During week 5 against the <a href="2021%20Washington%20Football%20Team%20season">Washington Football Team</a> Winston and the Saints overcame two early turnovers to beat Washington 33–22 while throwing for 279 yards, 4 touchdowns and 1 interception, along with a fumble.
In Week 8 against the <a href="2021%20Tampa%20Bay%20Buccaneers%20season">Tampa Bay Buccaneers</a>, Winston went 6 of 10 for 56 yards and one touchdown, along with 4 rushes for 40 yards before having to leave the game in the second quarter due to a knee injury after being <a href="horse-collar%20tackle">horse-collar tackle</a>d by Tampa Bay linebacker <a href="Devin%20White">Devin White</a>. He would be replaced by <a href="Trevor%20Siemian">Trevor Siemian</a>, who went on to win the game, 36–27. The next day, it was revealed that Winston had suffered a <a href="Anterior%20cruciate%20ligament%20injury">torn ACL</a> and had <a href="Medial%20knee%20injuries">MCL damage</a>, ending his season.
Personal life.
Winston married his wife, Breion Allen, in a private ceremony held at their home on March 27, 2020. They have one son together.
Controversies.
Sexual assault allegation.
On November 14, 2013, the <a href="State%27s%20attorney">State Attorney</a> of the <a href="Second%20Judicial%20Circuit%20Court%20of%20Florida">Second Judicial Circuit</a> announced they were opening an investigation into a sexual assault allegation involving Winston that was originally filed with the <a href="Tallahassee%20Police%20Department">Tallahassee Police Department</a> (TPD) on December 7, 2012. The complaint was originally investigated by the police and classified as open/inactive in February 2013 with no charges being filed. The police report, containing the complainant's original statement, has been posted by the Tallahassee Police Department. Tallahassee police stated that the complaint was made inactive "when the victim in the case broke off contact with TPD, and her attorney indicated she did not want to move forward at that time" and then re-examined after media requests for information started coming in early November. On December 5, 2013, State Attorney Willie Meggs announced the completion of the investigation and that no charges would be filed against anyone in this case, citing "major issues" with the woman's testimony. Meggs stated that "As prosecutors, we only bring charges for cases where the evidence will result in a likely conviction at trial. In this case, the evidence does not show that." Allegations of improper police conduct have been made by both parties, with the complainant claiming to have been pressured into dropping her claim and Winston's attorney alleging inappropriate leaks to the media. Florida State's policy is that athletes charged with a felony cannot play until their case is resolved, but Winston continued to play throughout the investigation because he was never charged.
On April 16, 2014, "<a href="The%20New%20York%20Times">The New York Times</a>" reported irregularities in the rape investigation involving Winston. The complainant developed bruises and semen was found on her underwear. 34 days later, the complainant identified Winston by name as her attacker. Tallahassee police contacted Winston about 13 days later. No DNA sample was taken from Winston until the prosecutor took over the case, months later; once it was taken in November 2013, it was found to match DNA found in the complainant's underwear. The investigation was conducted by Officer Scott Angulo, who, the "Times" article notes, did private security work for the Seminole Boosters, the primary financier of Florida State athletics.
The official FSU hearing, presided over by retired Florida Supreme Court Justice <a href="Major%20B.%20Harding">Major B. Harding</a>, on December 21, 2014, cleared Winston of violating the student conduct code in the sexual assault allegation. An extract from Harding's decision is below.
I do not find the credibility of one story substantially stronger than that of the other. Both have their own strengths and weaknesses. I cannot find with any confidence that the events as set forth by you, (accuser), or a particular combination thereof is more probable than not as required to find you responsible for a violation of the Code. Therein lies the determinative factor of my decision.
The accuser filed a civil suit against Winston in April 2014 and Winston countersued her for <a href="defamation">defamation</a> and <a href="tortious%20interference">tortious interference</a> in May 2014. In a September 2015 ruling, federal judge <a href="Anne%20C.%20Conway">Anne C. Conway</a> dismissed Winston's tortious interference claim, but declined a motion to dismiss his claim for defamation. These civil claims were settled out of court in December 2016, four months before the case was scheduled to go to trial.
In November 2015, Winston told <a href="CNN">CNN</a> that he was prepared to file suit if the network aired "<a href="The%20Hunting%20Ground">The Hunting Ground</a>", a documentary about college campus rape which includes disputed allegations about Winston. CNN was undeterred and aired the documentary on November 22, 2015.<ref name="McCarthy_11/22/2015"></ref>
In 2016, the university paid $950,000 to settle a lawsuit brought by the same woman alleging a violation of <a href="Title%20IX">Title IX</a> by FSU in handling her complaint. The university also agreed to conduct five years of sexual awareness programs. It did not admit liability.
Shoplifting incidents.
In July 2013, a <a href="Burger%20King">Burger King</a> employee called police in July to complain that Winston was stealing soda. According to the police report, Winston came into the restaurant with three men, but did not order any food. An employee, who recognized him, first saw him using ketchup cups to take some soda. He asked for a water cup after she told him to stop, but he said he would use it for soda and filled it repeatedly with soda over her objections, the report said. On April 29, 2014, Winston was issued an <a href="Summary%20offence%23United%20States">adult civil citation</a> for shoplifting <a href="crab%20legs">crab legs</a> from a Tallahassee <a href="Publix">Publix</a> store. Winston was ordered to undergo 20 hours of <a href="community%20service">community service</a>, and was suspended from any college baseball activity until he completed his community service.
Vulgar comments.
On September 17, 2014, Winston was suspended for the first half of Florida State's upcoming game against Clemson. "<a href="The%20Guardian">The Guardian</a>" reported that "several students tweeted" that Winston shouted, "<a href="List%20of%20Internet%20phenomena%23Videos">Fuck her right in the pussy</a>!" an <a href="Internet%20meme">Internet meme</a>, while standing atop a table in Florida State University's Student Union. Two days later, university president <a href="Garnett%20S.%20Stokes">Garnett S. Stokes</a> and athletic director Stan Wilcox, citing results of an "ongoing investigation", announced that Winston would be suspended for the whole game.
2017 groping allegation.
On November 17, 2017, it was reported that the NFL conducted an investigation, where Winston allegedly groped a female <a href="Uber">Uber</a> driver in 2016. Two days later, it was revealed that <a href="Ronald%20Darby">Ronald Darby</a>, who also attended Florida State, was also on board during the ride in which this incident supposedly occurred. Darby has defended Winston against the allegations. However, the investigation found evidence that Winston got into another Uber ride alone, which was consistent with the Uber driver's account, and concluded that Winston "violated the Personal Conduct Policy by touching the driver in an
inappropriate and sexual manner without her consent". The league announced on June 21 that it was suspending Winston for the first three games of the <a href="2018%20NFL%20season">2018 season</a> as a result of his involvement in the incident, which it carried through on June 28.
